definitions.definition: Of fire , etc.: no longer alight ; of a light , etc.: no longer shining ; extinguished , quenched .
examples: Edward’s cigarillo was extinct by the time he had finished talking.

subdefinitions.definition: Of feelings , a person 's spirit , a state of affairs , etc.: put out , as if like a fire; quenched, suppressed .

Of customs , ideas , laws and legal rights , offices , organizations , etc.: no longer existing or in use ; defunct , discontinued , obsolete ; specifically, of a title of nobility : no longer having any person qualified to hold it.
examples: Luckily, such ideas about race are extinct in current sociological theory.
The title became extinct when the last baron died.

subdefinitions.definition: Of an animal or plant species , a class of people , a family , etc.: having died out completely ; no longer in existence .
examples: Dinosaurs have been extinct for millions of years.

subdefinitions.definition: Of a geological feature : no longer active ; specifically, of a volcano : no longer erupting .
examples: Most of the volcanos on this island are now extinct .
They found the sites of extinct geysers.

subdefinitions.definition: Of a radioisotope : no longer occurring primordially due to having decayed away completely , because it has a relatively short half-life .
Of a person: dead ; also, permanently separated from others.

main_definition: ( dated ) Of fire , etc.: no longer alight ; of a light , etc.: no longer shining ; extinguished , quenched .
